newsitem.title: GHANA: Ghana's exports branch away from gold and cocoa.
newsitem.headline: Ghana's exports branch away from gold and cocoa.

text.p: Ghana's non-traditional exports rose by over 75 percent in 1996 and state incentives are in place to further cut dependency on gold and cocoa revenues, a Ghanaian export council official said.

Non-traditional export earnings from products as diverse as shark fins and veneer rose to $276.2 million in 1996 from $155.6 million in 1995, spearheaded by processed and semi-processed products, Ghana's Export Promotion Council (GEPC) Deputy-Director, Kwabena Boateng, told Reuters.

"(Ghana's) government has allocated a sizeable amount of money with the financial sector (for 1997) to promote genuine exporters of non-traditional products," Boateng said. He expected that to produce even better results this year.
"If the performance during the first quarter of the year is anything to go by, then we expect nothing less than a 50 percent increase in (non-traditional) earnings this year over 1996."
Ghana's Cocoa Board said last week that cocoa export earnings in 1996 totalled $568.2 million, against $589.2 million for the country's main export, gold.
Ghana has said it will encourage more local processing of cocoa beans in future to raise value-added exports.
The latest GEPC data showed processed and semi-processed products, led by wood, earned $233 million in 1996 against $130.2 million in 1995, Boateng said.

Wood product earnings totalled $66.89 million, against $37.54 in 1995, and came mainly from furniture, plywood, veneer and builders' materials. Handicrafts earned $2.9 million against $2 million, he added.
Agricultural products earnings rose to $50.27 million from $27.38 million, led by horticulture and seafood exports.

Horticultural earnings grew by almost 80 percent to $20.7 million from $11.5 million, with pineapples earning $11 million from 27,602 tonnes exported. That compared with $5.6 million from 15,763 tonnes in the previous year.
Fish and other seafoods -- including shark fins, tuna and shrimp -- earned $12.3 million against $7.3 million over the same periods, Boateng said.
